comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: There's no DOG!!!  How can you have that many horses and not have a dog to bark at them?  It's not natural I say.  Great shot of the old pub - when it was an hotel no less!

comment.author: 41675580@N08
comment._content: I love the old picture, great find but that was a good point, not  dog in sight.  Did someone SHOOT the poor brutes?

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Do you know where this was/is then, Sean? Would love a Google Maps link. Think we need to get [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley/] to do a Google Maps linking seminar with you...  :)

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/alimarante] I reckon it's the slow speed. Dogs zoom about in excitement, probably too fast to even leave a blur in these early shots...

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: A dandy indeed. The man to his left looks like he could buy the whole of Kildare.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: It's a Hotel on the OS 25" from 1908. If you flip to the 1838 6", it's the Blackchurch Inn.

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Lol the dandy!! He certainly loves himself! What a cracking shot - just as I was about to read Pride and Prejudice ....again!

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] On a road out towards Naas and the races?

comment.author: 30622421@N03
comment._content: Landaus were 4 seater convertables while broughams seem to be two seaters. So a landau. I found this link www.arnkarnk.plus.com/glossary.htm

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
No racecourse in Naas in 1908, but Punchestown was there since the 1860s.

Or it could be a point to point.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Flipping between maps on the OS site says the front door is still in precisely the same spot: Streetview

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Delighted with the Punchestown info, Niall. That ties in very nicely with next Monday's photos...

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] I'm far from knowledgeable on horse-drawn vehicles, but that extra, exterior rear seat on the coach might make it something other than a Landau. Presumably for the servants or other underlings.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/vab2009] Excellent, thank you! Think it must be a Landau alright because of elliptical springs which this one seems to have...

comment.author: 48020153@N07
comment._content: great

comment.author: 65379774@N02
comment._content: In the 1980s Brendan Grace (Comedian) ran the Inn with his family,he would fit nicely into the 1875 photograph,beard and all.

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] As I said. I'm far from knowledgeable about these matters. A quick googleing found me a few mentions of the Black Church Inn in various Thoms Directories, with Daniel Vicars, Peter Vicars and Patrick Vicars listed as proprietors in various years. D. Vickers on the sign above the door so Thom's must have had the spelling wrong. 1911 census has a Peter Vickers, farmer and publican, in Steelstown, Newcastle, Co. Dublin.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] No I think I will stick with DannyM8. Believe it or not the first thing I thought about when seeing this photo earlier was Punchestown!!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here is Peter Vickers in 1901. He lists his occupation as farming only, and Steelstown is mis-transcribed as Stutstown.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: The Blackchurch Inn and Restaurant is actually about 400m on the Dublin side of the county border with Kildare.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] So, our proprietor would be Daniel Vickers then?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Aha, not Kildare at all then?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] You'll like Monday's photos then...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Finding "Daniel Vicars" listed as proprietor of the Black Church Inn, in the 1861, 1862 and 1865 Thom's Directories. Vicars of the Black Church. Daniel Vickers it is so. There's a P. Vickers still owning it as late as 1950.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Sorry Carol, the Boss isn't well and God help her I'm playing nursey so I missed your request for location.  Because you're from down the wesht (?) you would not have known the Black Church Inn as us mid-west and southern folk would.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] ...and the 1868 lists Paul Vicars, so this dates from 1860-1868.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: It does look very gentrified and grand with the drivers in livery but is it possible that this was a Bianconi carriage taking punters to the races?  A shilling for the inside seats and a tanner for the fresh air seats???

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: Blackpool landaus do not have the extra "dickie" seat at the back, but the folding hoods are just as in the NLI photo. Here is my photo of a landau. www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach/1497841194 They have to have dung catchers now.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/65379774@N02] He would fit in, John, thanks for the Brendan Grace connection.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms] Think we can go with 1860-67, given that Paul Vickers must have taken over in time to be included in the 1868 Directory...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Send our best regards to the Boss! Hope she feels better soon... And "from the Wesht"? Not at all - Dublin with a good dollop of Waterford thrown into the mix! Bianconi coach is a good suggestion, but I think they tended to be longer - what were know as "long cars", and were designed to carry a lot more people.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] As do all horse drawn carriages still plying their trade in Dublin - have dung catchers, that is - and penalty points for jarveys in Killarney...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
I am looking at a book - Peerless Punchestown 150 years of glorious tradition. Our photograph is reproduced on page 5 with the following caption "Returning from Punchestown in 1868..at what was then for many a mandatory stop at the Blackchurch Inn for "Refreshments"

Interesting date!!

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] If they're returning from the races, then that dandy must have backed a winner.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] That's excellent, Danny, and definitely in our ballpark date established by [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] and [http://www.flickr.com/photos/eyelightfilms]! Maybe I was being too sticky about dates for Daniel versus Paul Vickers in the Dublin Directories - could just have been that Paul didn't get the D. Vickers sign changed immediately on taking up proprietorship? So dubbing this photo circa 1868. Your Punchestown confirmation is also great, given the 2 photos I'll be uploading on Monday. And you've also inadvertently revealed a gap in our collections, Danny. We've lots of sporting books by Raymond Smith, but not Peerless Punchestown...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland]  I will leave it to the Library in my will....

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] Will hold you to that promise! :)
